concern:
tw suicide mention 

Title says it all. I joined my sorority during informal recruitment my sophomore year (last spring) and never really became close with anyone. I studied abroad last semester (maybe a bad idea in hindsight) and now it seems like I’m being excluded out of malicious intent. Yesterday was the cherry on top. Not gonna go into detail, but I went to an event and spoke to absolutely no one in my chapter. I feel like everyone hates me. It does take me a long time to warm up to people because I was severely bullied and abused K-12, and I wish with everything in me that I could fix it. After the event, I sobbed in my car while taking to my mom for an hour. I don’t want to bring the chapter down anymore. The only reason why I’m still in it is because it looks good on resumes. It’s honestly starting to make me suicidal. Any advice is appreciated.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! It's great to have you here. I'd love to hear what's on your mind. What's been going on lately that you'd like to talk about?
I've been struggling with feelings of exclusion in my social circle, which has been really affecting my mental health. I'm here to work on building better connections and managing these emotions.

It sounds like you're feeling isolated and disconnected from your friends, and that's really impacting your well-being. That must be really tough. Can you tell me more about what's been happening that's making you feel excluded?

I've been experiencing ongoing situations where I feel left out by people in my social group, which has left me feeling increasingly isolated and down. I'm hoping to explore ways to improve my social interactions and cope with these emotions more effectively.

It's clear that these feelings of exclusion are having a significant impact on your mental health and sense of belonging. It's great that you're taking steps to address this issue. Have you tried reaching out to any of your friends to express how you're feeling and discuss ways to improve your interactions?

I haven't reached out to my friends about this because I'm worried it might make the situation worse, given my past experiences. I'm hoping therapy can help me build the confidence to try that in the future.

It's understandable that you're hesitant to reach out to your friends due to past experiences, and it's great that you're seeking support in therapy. Building confidence to communicate your feelings is an important step. Can you think of any small, safe steps you might take to start expressing your feelings to your friends?

I could start by writing down my feelings in a journal to practice articulating them, which might make it less overwhelming. Then, I might share a simple, positive comment with a friend to test the waters without diving into deeper issues.

Starting with journaling to articulate your feelings and then sharing a positive comment with a friend are excellent first steps to build confidence in expressing yourself. These actions can help create a sense of safety and control while testing the waters. How would you like to track your progress with these steps and when do you plan to start?

I could track my progress by keeping a simple journal entry after each step, rating my comfort level on a scale of 1 to 10. I plan to start journaling tonight and aim to share a positive comment with a friend by the end of this week.

It's great to see you taking these proactive steps towards building confidence in expressing your feelings and improving your social interactions. Journaling your emotions and sharing positive comments with friends are excellent starting points. Tracking your comfort level in your journal after each step will help you monitor your progress. Good luck with your journaling tonight, and I look forward to hearing about your experiences sharing with a friend by the end of the week. Remember, small steps can lead to significant changes over time. I'll be here to support you along the way.
Thanks for your support I'll start journaling tonight to build my confidence and ease the isolation I'm feeling. See you next time.
